title: Make your way through the poke mansion
description:
Sprites from spriters-resource; music from khinsider. 

This was pretty tricky! Originally I tried to set it up so that if you were at certain xy coordinates that would trigger the floor transition but for some reason wasn't able to get the detection set up right, so I settled for making different stair sprites. 


Next up - real walls!
instructions: Walk around using the arrow keys to find the right staircase to navigate between floors.

title: Jack Charles: On A Mission!
description: My most prized moment was figuring out how to keep the shoes on jack after he puts them on!!
instructions:
For today I made a little maze for my dog- can you help him find his shoes!? Once you find them, simply answer yes or no as to whether you'd like him to keep them on!

Use the arrow keys to help jack find the shoes! Once you find them, go to them to put them on!

title: Quest
description:
This project was created for Day 12 of Getting Unstuck. 
I've seen a few projects like this and always wanted to try making one. Today's Getting Unstuck challenge provided the perfect opportunity.

The rooms were drawn with the Scratch vector editor. Other media were mostly scavenged on pixabay.com

Music: 
Daniel Birch, Atmosphere
Claude Debussy, Suite Bergamasque Prelude (Claudio Colombo)
instructions: Click the green flag to begin this epic quest. Use the arrow keys to navigate. Good luck!

title: Escape The Room
description:
At the moment, I am feeling more proud of this project than anything else I've created. :) I'm obsessed with escape rooms and I've long wanted to make one in Scratch. Today's Getting Unstuck prompt (Day 12, "Make a project that includes three separate scenes that a sprite moves through.") seemed like the perfect reason to try!

I'm definitely enjoying a self-congratulatory "WOW!" moment. I hope you enjoy it! If I had more time, I would definitely add more challenges.

I took the soundscape from @jsh's "Space Chomp" https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/1735345/
instructions:
Press the green flag.
Help the Scratch Cat.

title: quahoggin'
description:
I was inspired by @mizzpeters to return to my first ever scratch project, or, the inspiration behind my first scratch projects - Surf Cat Summer and Surf Cat Clams, created after finding a secret beach with friends.

For this project I decided I'd explore the vector editor and a walk cycle with the changing scenes. After a bit of playing, I enjoyed using the vector editor and I'm excited to continue to work with it. I'm feeling OK about the walk cycle for a first go -- would like to create more steps so that it appears smoother. Continuing with the project I'd also like for the background to appear as moving, too! I started to look into scrolling sprites, though that will be a challenge for another day (: I'd also like to have interactive features with each scene.

-- [ Started from the bottom, now I'm here! ] --
Surf Cat Summer + Surf Cat Clams here:
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/175038091
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/175039887
--[As seen in these projects, I can create SO MUCH MORE now!!!]--

sound sources:
https://freesound.org/people/straget/sounds/411206/
https://freesound.org/people/DasDeer/sounds/161815/
https://freesound.org/people/InspectorJ/sounds/400632/
https://freesound.org/people/13FPanska_Marval_Lukas/sounds/379334/
instructions:
Press the green flag, then press the space bar.

Once in the ocean, move around with the up, down, left, and right arrow keys to find a quahog!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 12 — Moving Rooms
description:
Reflection

This is a remix of my Day 5 project which allows the user to control Scratchy by making him move and jump. This upgrade adds the ability to move rooms.

How does it work? When Scratchy touches the left or right edge, the room number changes, and the background updates accordingly.

While this is a small update, the size of the world has gotten so much bigger.
instructions:
Move with LEFT and RIGHT arrows.
Jump with SPACEBAR.

title: Where is Mrs. Pollard?
description:
Turtle from PlusPNG.com
Computer Lab Teacher artwork by a former 2nd-grade student
Photos by me.

Reflections:  I notice that I tend to get stuck when I jump right in without a plan for the project.  I like to be creative but planning out all the scenes, Sprites and animations ahead of time will help with deciding which algorithm to use for the flow of the project.

Stuck: I had a tricky time getting the bubbles to show and hide on cue. Better planning would have saved time debugging/recoding.

Ironically, I would insist my students have a well-defined plan before I would let them start a project such as this.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck #12 Use Scenes

Press the spacebar. Wait. Repeat. Enjoy.

title: Getting Unstuck 12
description:
I had no time and no ideas today, so I remixed a wonderful little project by @TheGreatMe11 to include fading in of three totally inappropriate background (actually stored in sprites to make the fading work. Did you know you can drag a backdrop into a sprite and it will become a costume? Took a minute or five to fix a weird glitch that turned out to be due to having one of the chosen backgrounds as the actual background which would show through sometimes. I fixed that by leaving it for a while - when I came back it was obvious. Looking for that bug, I found a more subtle bug that also got fixed - so often the case when debugging.)

If I had more time I would go to the shops as there's not much in the fridge.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 12
Make a project that includes three separate scenes that a sprite moves through. 

Click the green flag and enjoy!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 12
description: Credit: NASA

title: Day 12 Getting Unstuck
description:
Challenge: Make a project that includes three separate scenes that a sprite moves through. 

This was pretty straightforward to create, but it gave me a chance to use custom blocks to simplify the code. I also had to use two sprites unexpectedly in order to add a pose in the end that wasn't part of the first sprites walking costumes. Finally, I discovered that you can change the stage backdrop from a sprite without having to broadcast to the stage.

title: A Lovely Day
description:
For today's Getting Unstuck challenge, I modified a scrolling script to create multiple scenes along a walk.

Scene one is in the lab. 

Scene two is walking past a sunflower patch, remixing a beautiful pen solution from Scratcher scmb1:
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235674874/

The third scene is a butterfly passing by.

I interpreted the second and third scenes as interactions vs. specific backdrops. My next plan is to add an evening fireworks display using the script from the Fireworks projets by Scratcher 77Tigers: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/195160155/
instructions:
Press the green flag to go for a walk with Avery.

Use the left and right arrow keys (mostly right) to walk around.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 12
description: Not really a WOW moment, but was interesting to clock that I could get the name of the backdrop as the message.

title: Falling apple...
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 12
by Massimo Marletta

A simulation on gravity acting on a falling apple.
I used 3 scenes, representing 3 different gravitational system: Earth, Moon and Jupiter.
In each of them you can simulated an apple falling subjected to the gravity force. The timer is used to keep time and increment the apple's velocity of a constant quantity (which is the acceleration of gravity, g) depending on the particular gravitational system.
The time of the simulation is slowed down to let you observe the motion. As you can see the total falling time is different in different planets due to the different value of g.
instructions:
A simulation on gravity acting on a falling apple (by Isaac Newton, not Steve Jobs).

Click on the scene to select a planet (Earth, Moon, Jupiter) or click on the apple to make it fall down.

The time of the simulation is slowed down to let you observe the motion. As you can see the total falling time is different in different planets due to the different value of the acceleration of gravity.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 12 Moving thru 3 Scenes
To the moon!
description:
Obviously this is a remake of the classic game "Lander". The spaceship comes from another game of mine (check "planet seeder" and "orbiter"). The vector of the spaceship is modified by the sine and cosine function of the angle.
Fun fact: I never fully understood what a sine and cosine were until a made a game which used them. It was a driving game made in (then Macromedia) Flash. Maybe one way for understanding something is trying to do a videogame about it!
Explosion by Naveenan on Pixabay https://pixabay.com/en/comic-blast-blast-effect-2340467/
instructions:
UP = thrust, LEFT, RIGHT = rotation, SPACE = ignition
Try to get to the moon of the alien planet. 
You start on Earth, just press up to win gravity until you reach outer space.
In space you have to manouver to the moon revolving around the alien planet. There is no friction and gravity here.
On the moon you have to land. Beware! There is little gravity here and the spaceship can land only if it's pointing up and with very little speed (both horizontal and vertical)

title: Getting Unstuck day 12
description:
It took me a while to come up with an idea today. Once I did and got started, I realized that I would need more than 3 scenes. When it comes to telling a story, brevity is not my strong suit. I did my best to keep it concise. I am pleased with this project because it is a personal story. I think that's the most authentic possible use of Scratch, or any kind of creating really, when it is deeply personal. It may not be "wow" to everyone, but it IS "wow" for me.

final image by MrQuentin

title: Unstuck Day 12- Different Scenes
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #12-use at least 3 scenes- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
This took a long time because of the many assets I needed to make, but most of it came together pretty easily because I planned out how it would work. 
One thing was hard, which was I wanted to make the keys by just making one and having it clone itself when you find more. but that didn't work, it kept adding a lot each time. So I just made 6 keys.
instructions: Get the 6 keys to escape the room! Face different walls of the room by clicking the sides. There's a surprise when you get out. Good luck!!

title: Penguin Jumper Unstuck #8 & #12
description:
This project came from a book I bought at our Spring Book Fair. It's called "20 Games to Create With Scratch" by Max Waine Wright. 

I wanted to stretch my comfort level, especially since this project deals with variables. I've used variables for scoring, but not much else. I liked this idea because in addition to score it uses variables to set the speed and angle of the penguin. At first the game was too easy. All you had to do was point at the iceberg. I had to play around and tweak the speed and gap to get the penguin to launch at the angle I wanted.

I figured out how to add lives when a certain score is reached, but I'd like to be able to add a life at certain increments, for example at every multiple of 50. I'm sure it must be an easy math calculation, but I couldn't figure out how to do that. Any suggestions would be most appreciated.
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin. Aim the arrow and then click on it to send the penguin to the blue iceberg.

I added levels & scenes to this for Unstuck #12

Unfortunately. I have run out of time and must get to bed as I work early tomorrow.  I am sharing anyway and hope to complete it soon!

Music: Also includes the Beatles: Two of Us
Various pictures found on Liverpool chamber site.  Need more pictures to add and will in the future.
instructions:
Day 12 Challenge of Getting Unstuck: Make a project that includes three separate scenes that a sprite moves through. 

Ok, this one has gotten away from me and not done yet.  Press the green flag to see the intro to the project. It took a much longer to make than I had planned.   

Quickly added a little more this morning (7/17), so it can stand on it's on.  However, still plan to come back and work on it more to make it the way I originally envisioned.

title: Three Separate Scenes that a Sprite Moves Through
description: I had a different story line in mind when I started this project but the combo of backgrounds and sprites lead me to this final story line.
instructions: Click on the green flag and enjoy the story.

title: Tadpole adventure!!
description:
I've created a very short demo game.
I've wanted to create a platform game which combines other game elements. I decided to draw everything from scratch, and I'm proud of it. I used only a few scenes (6).

                                      ---My next goal---
I'd like to add more worlds, enemies, food, sound effects and to make a longer story.

                                          ----Credits----
+ Sprites and bakgrounds: All of them have been created with the Scratch paint editor.
+ Song: "NES level1" by Labbed is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License.
instructions:
---Welcome to Tadpole adventure---

Help your little tadpole to get home. Eat plankton to make you stronger. Every 12 pieces of plankton your tadpole will grow. The other fishes can grow too. 
When you are bigger than the fishes, they will be smaller and vice versa. 
Be careful with lava.
Get at least 23 pieces of plankton to win the game.
Enjoy it!

**Tips**: variable: food1 is for tadpole.
variable food2 is for fishes.
Tadpole only eat plankton with her little mouth.

                                        ---Controls---
Press the green flag and then click the button bellow to start.
Arrow keys to move your character.

                         ---Getting Unstuck Day 12---
"Make a project that includes three separate scenes that a sprite moves through."

title: Unstuck Day 12: Three Sequential Scenes
description:
Still draft version. Revised my earlier project to change scenes.
I was having fun making my underwater scene complex, with various sprites moving in different directions and using different types of motion. 
Used "broadcast" to backdrops scenes. Have a much better understanding of command after working on today's project. Still not perfect.  Have to get rid of unwanted sprites in certain scenes. Yesterday, I was following the pattern given during my remix, and today I was building my own code.  
Very funny to see sharks in space and fish flying. Know what to do, and fixed many errors, but project was glitchy and did always run properly.  (Too many lines of code?)

title: G.U.  Day 12 - QUATTRO PASSI ...
description: #NAME?
instructions:
Una della tante versioni  di " Quattro passi per Crevalcore" , un Progetto di Storia locale iniziato in Classe Prima , qui rappresentato come una passeggiata nel Centro Storico del paese. 
Uno degli obiettivi principali del Progetto era quello di riallacciare i fili della memoria e i legami con un territorio colpito dal sisma del 2012. E' stato un Progetto poliennale, che ha coinvolto bambini, insegnanti, genitori e nonni di due classi. 
Parte del Progetto  fa riferimento agli studi e alle attività di formazione del Prof. Vaccarelli, dell'Università dell'Aquila, relativi alla pedagogia dell'emergenza.
Il Centro Storico di Crevalcore, poi, è adattissimo per una Caccia al tesoro con Coding … (reale)

Questa versione è una copia modificata. 
Sequenze molto lunghe, con istruzioni che si ripetono. 
So già che avrei potuto usare delle combinazioni più complesse, ma più funzionali.
 Aspetto consigli e suggerimenti.

title: Dance with Friends
instructions: Click the Green Flag to begin.

title: Unstuck - Day 12
description:
This was a pretty simple challenge.  In the past, I have created projects where two characters are talking to one another in two different locations.  The characters would show and hide as the background switched.  
My goal in participating in this Unstuck 21 Day Challenge is to gather ideas for my classroom.  I would like to use these Unstuck projects as bell ringers to introduce students to new programming challenges.  Today's challenge will probably be used relatively early in my course, but I would bring it back later to ask students to either elaborate on a previous idea or challenge themselves to try something new.
instructions: Click the green flag to start.

title: Day 12:  Do the Honey Bee!
description:
This project is an example project I did for a Scratch Conference workshop that Cynthia Solomon and I are doing on "Atoms to Bits" with animation.  The Bee was lasercut in wood and painted, then I took a photo.  I uploaded the photo into scratch, made it into a sprite and then animated the sprite.

I learned that cutting out a photo with the magic wand turns it grey, so you have to use the erase tool.  I used my chain reaction broadcast scheme like a boss, again!

The song is from the Point View School Kids Hip Hop Honeybee dance.  Google the video. . . it's very cute!
instructions:
Just press the green flag and enjoy.

The bee is an actual necklace that I made in the South End Technology Center @ Tent City's Fab Lab in Boston.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 12
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 12 Reflection:
I hope it's okay to use this project for day 12, since it's one I just made for a Scratch class I'm taking.  I wowed myself by creating different scenes from the doorways, and I was surprised how hard it was to make my scripts match up to the idea I had in my head.  It's still not exactly what I wanted, but I'm learning more with each day of Getting Unstuck and with each project I make.
Clip art images from openclipart.org.

title: Wandering - Getting Unstuck 12
description:
The main credits is to the long novels "Intraworld" by Neil Gaiman and Michael Reaves, which you need to know to fully appreciate this work. Or at least go in a library or a bookstore and peruse a couple of pages, please ;-) 
I used the english translation of the italian title to have an excuse for creating a 007 like intro.
The hardest things to obtain was to enlarge the text beyond the maximum size allowed by Scratch and obtain the spiral effect zooming out the text. It uses a trick I had to google hard to find.
AND YOU CAN HAVE TO ALMOST FREE: just open the project and read the code (ask for help in the comment if needed)!

https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/Overriding_the_Costume_Size_Limit
instructions:
Just click, on the green flag, click when required and enjoy.

I had no idea on what to do for this project and then created one describing that impasse, and gives an hint on the way I solved it, or, better got unstucked!

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 12
description: Didn't have much time to work on! I wanted to create something fun and was inspired by recently watching Inception.
instructions: Press the green flag to start.

title: Visiting the house of Scratch
description:
My original idea was to share some of the places I'm going to visit during my upcoming holidays, visiting my friends and family in Italy.
I wanted to start the journey by going out of the Media Lab, but I realized that it would have been cool to let other people in the lab, to visit this incredibly playful and inspiring place.

I'm pretty satisfied with the project, especially because I was able to make it in a short time. Yesterday I've been spending hours working on a different project idea but I realized that I need more time for that.

So my design response to this project is "yes!", I hope it might be "wow!" for someone else! :)

Enjoy!
instructions: Click the green flag and enjoy a quick tour of the MIT Media Lab, home of Scratch!
